questions.solution:
Satellite lesions are a characteristic finding of fungal keratitis. These multifocal stromal infiltrates appear as small, round, white lesions surrounding a central ulcer. They are often considered a hallmark feature of fungal infections of the cornea. The presence of these satellite lesions is a key indicator for diagnosing fungal keratitis, particularly when the integrity of the epithelial surface is compromised, allowing the fungus to invade the tissue.

Incorrect Options:

B. Dendritic ulcer
Dendritic ulcers are typically associated with herpes simplex virus (HSV) keratitis, not fungal infections. They appear as branching, tree-like patterns on the corneal surface and are not characteristic of fungal keratitis.

C. Ring abscess
Ring abscesses are more commonly seen in bacterial keratitis, particularly with pseudomonas infections. They can appear as a ring-shaped infiltrate with an abscess, but they are not a typical finding in fungal keratitis.

D. White Hypopyon
A white hypopyon refers to the accumulation of white blood cells (WBCs) in the anterior chamber, which is usually associated with inflammatory conditions like infectious keratitis or uveitis, but it is not a specific finding for fungal keratitis. While hypopyon can be present in fungal keratitis, a white hypopyon is more characteristic of bacterial infections.

Key Takeaway: The presence of satellite lesions is a characteristic finding of fungal keratitis, which involves multifocal stromal infiltrates surrounding a central ulcer. This feature helps differentiate fungal infections from other types of keratitis.

Reference: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Fungal_Keratitis

questions.text: Which vitamin in supraphysiologic doses causes macular oedema and a a macular cyst ?
questions.solution:
CME is a disorder that involves the central retina, caused by an accumulation of extracellular fluid in the macular region with secondary formation of multiple cystic spaces. Histological studies show that radially orientated cystoid spaces consisting of ophthalmoscopically clear fluid are often clinically detectable in the macula area. These cysts seem to be areas of the retina in which the cells have been displaced. It is the result of cystic accumulation of extracellular intraretinal fluid in the outer plexiform and inner nuclear layers of the retina.

The exact pathogenesis of CME remains uncertain. CME following disruption of the blood-retinal barrier (BRB). When the BRB is damaged, fluid accumulates within the retina both intra- and extracellularly . Müller cells are thought to play an important role in acting as metabolic pumps that keep the macula dehydrated. However, intracellular fluid accumulation in the Müller cells may also occur in CME and further reduce macular retinal function. Vitreous traction may also play a part in the development of CME . Macular edema is the most frequent and severe complications of pars planitis, HLA-B27-associated acute anterior uveitis, sarcoidosis, birdshot retinochoroidopathy, Behcet's syndrome, toxoplasmosis, Eales' disease, idiopathic vitritis, Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome, and scleritis. CME can follow cataract surgery in the Irvine-Gass syndrome, because after cataract surgery, inflammatory mediators from the anterior chamber diffuse posteriorly into the vitreous, causing leakage from the retinal vasculature.

CME is the consequence of diabetic retinopathy. The edema in the macular area occurs secondary to an abnormal permeability of the capillaries surrounding the macula (failure of inner retinal blood barrier), and in turn to a failure in the outer retinal barrier (formed by the retinal pigmented epithelium). Retinal vein obstructions (RVO) represent another cause of CME. Increased rigidity of a crossing artery because an atherosclerotic process has been suggested to cause compression of the underlying vein, provoking turbulent blood flow, endothelial damage, and thrombus formation. Likewise, a common vitreous adhesion at the obstruction site has also been reported, suggesting a possible role of vitreovascular traction in the etiology of some cases of BRVO. Atherosclerosis is a chronic low-grade inflammatory disorder and inflammation within the vascular wall contributes to the development of CME . Due to BRB breakdown secondary to damage at the tight junctions of endothelial cells, fluid diffusion from the occluded veins into the tissue can lead to CME. In addition, through such mechanisms, inflammatory responses and vascular dysfunction can all interact to cause retinal ischemia, which induces the expression of VEGF and others inflammatory agents, which participate in a complex chain of events that has yet to be fully defined.

Many authors reported ocular side effect after therapy with niacin. Fraunfelder et al. reported that 3 g or more per day of nicotinic acid, could cause blurred vision, eyelid edema, toxic amblyopia, proptosis, loss of eyelashes or eyebrow, superficial punctate keratitis and CME. Some cases of blurred vision were reported in the literature , and 18 cases were reported to the National Registry or the FDA spontaneous reporting system. In these cases, the average dose of niacin was 1.5-2 g per day, with a duration of therapy varying from 6 weeks to 1 year. Follow-up reported complete resolution of visual symptoms after discontinuing niacin. Dry eye was explained because this vitamin may be secreted and concentrated in human tears, thereby irritating an already dry eye. Niacin can cause ocular signs and symptoms reversible dose related, so if the patient wishes to continue this therapy, it may be feasible to reduce the dose of the drug . Cases of niacin related maculopathy there is a 10:1 male: female ratio. Most cases were in their third to fifth decade of life and were being treated with an average dose of 3-6 g of niacin per day. The etiology of niacin's effect on the macula is unknown, A first hypothesis suggests that, in patients with vascular or inflammatory diseases, niacin induces the release of prostaglandins, causing the blood-retinal barrier compromise with extracellular accumulation of fluid in many cystic spaces. This theory is not entirely accepted for the absence of fluorescein leakage.

The second and the most reliable hypothesis supports that the niacin has a direct toxic effect on Müller cells, without disruption of the blood-retinal-barrier. Alterations in cellular metabolism cause intracellular fluid increase and swelling of these cells, with secondary formation of cysts between the glial spaces. After the discontinuation of niacin therapy, there is a complete regeneration of the Müller cells and their normal function . Reports from the literature suggest that the onset of maculopathy ranges from 1 to 36 months after initiation of relatively high-dose therapy (3 g or more daily). There have also been reports of this condition with lower dosages (1.5 g daily). This patient had increased the dosage of niacin to 3 g daily nearly 2 months before documentation of CME. In a previous case report a very low dose of niacin was administered (18 mg) and niacin maculopathy appears 4 weeks later with a complete resolution after discontinuation of drug, confirming the relationship between drug administration and macular edema appearance. In this patient, funduscopic examination showed bilateral macular edema, but no signs of diabetic or hypertensive retinopathy excluding the presence of other factors that may contribute to the capillary dysfunction associated with edema onset. At funduscopic examination, the foveomacular area had a peculiar aspect: the foveola takes on a bright yellow hue, similar to an exudate. Cysts primarily involve the foveal area, and they are smaller than those seen in post-surgical or inflammatory CME . FA and OCT are useful to confirm the diagnosis. FA showed the absence of fluorescein leakage or vascular alteration, whereas OCT confirms the presence of cystic hyporeflective spaces in the outer plexiform and inner nuclear layers. The cystoid spaces were more numerous and larger in the outer plexiform layer compared with the inner nuclear layer. Indeed previous studies reported that the fluor-angiographic pattern is atypical.

On the left, there is an image of Stratus OCT 2 weeks after the start of niacin treatment. On the right fluorescein angiography of the same patient after 3 weeks after the beginning of niacin treatment with the typical absence of leakage also in later phases

Gass described reversible bilateral CME with no angiographic fluorescein leakage in 3 patients taking doses of niacin greater than 1.5 g daily to treat hyperlipidemia . Although Gass described transmitted hyper-fluorescence with a cartwheel pattern in the fluorescein angiograms of his patients, later reports described typical fluorescence in similarly affected patients. In all these cases, symptoms resolved over 4 to 8 weeks following discontinuation of niacin. First-line treatment for CME of toxic origin, such as that induced by niacin, is the removal of the offending agent. In milder cases of maculopathy, symptoms have resolved within a few days of drug discontinuation.

Incorrect Options:

A. Vitamin-A

While Vitamin-A deficiency can lead to night blindness and other vision issues, it is not typically associated with macular edema or macular cysts. However, excessive intake of Vitamin A can lead to toxicity, but this primarily causes other issues such as hypervitaminosis A and does not generally result in macular edema or cysts.

B. Vitamin-D

While Vitamin-D toxicity is associated with hypercalcemia, which can lead to kidney stones, bone pain, and other systemic effects, but it is not typically linked to macular edema or macular cyst formation.

C. Vitamin-E

While Vitamin E is a potent antioxidant, excessive intake generally leads to bleeding and other side effects but is not commonly associated with macular edema or cyst formation.

Key Takeaway: Niacin (Vitamin B3) in supraphysiologic doses can cause macular edema and the formation of macular cysts, which is an important consideration when using niacin for treating high cholesterol or other conditions requiring high doses of this vitamin.

Sympathetic ophthalmia (SO), also called spared eye injury, is a diffuse granulomatous inflammation of the uveal layer of both eyes following trauma to one eye. It can leave the affected person completely blind. Symptoms may develop from days to several years after a penetrating eye injury. It typically results from a delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

Signs and symptoms

Eye floaters and loss of accommodation are among the earliest symptoms. The disease may progress to severe inflammation of the uveal layer of the eye (uveitis) with pain and sensitivity of the eyes to light. The affected eye often remains relatively painless while the inflammatory disease spreads through the uvea, where characteristic focal infiltrates in the choroid named Dalén-Fuchs nodules can be seen. The retina, however, usually remains uninvolved, although perivascular cuffing of the retinal vessels with inflammatory cells may occur. Swelling of the optic disc (papilledema), secondary glaucoma, vitiligo, and poliosis of the eyelashes may accompany SO.

Pathophysiology

Sympathetic ophthalmia is currently thought to be an autoimmune inflammatory response toward ocular antigens, specifically a delayed hypersensitivity to melanin-containing structures from the outer segments of the photoreceptor layer of the retina. The immune system, which normally is not exposed to ocular proteins, is introduced to the contents of the eye following traumatic injury. Once exposed, it senses these antigens as foreign, and begins attacking them. The onset of this process can be from days to years after the inciting traumatic event.

Diagnosis

Diagnosis is clinical, seeking a history of eye injury. An important differential diagnosis is Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome (VKH), which is thought to have the same pathogenesis, without a history of surgery or penetrating eye injury.

Still experimental, skin tests with soluble extracts of human or bovine uveal tissue are said to elicit delayed hypersensitivity responses in these patients. Additionally, circulating antibodies to uveal antigens have been found in patients with SO and VKH, as well as those with long-standing uveitis, making this a less than specific assay for SO and VKH.

Treatment

Because SO is so rarely encountered following eye injury, even when the injured eye is retained, the first choice of treatment may not be enucleation or evisceration, especially if there is a chance that the injured eye may regain some function. Additionally, with current advanced surgical techniques, many eyes once considered nonviable now have a fair prognosis.

However, only if the injured eye has completely lost its vision and has no potential for any visual recovery, prevention of SO is done by enucleation of the injured eye preferably within the first 2 weeks of injury. Evisceration-the removal of the contents of the globe while leaving the sclera and extraocular muscles intact-is easier to perform, offers long-term orbital stability, and is more aesthetically pleasing, i.e., a greater measure of movement of the prosthesis and thus a more natural appearance. There is concern, however, that evisceration may lead to a higher incidence of SO compared to enucleation. Several retrospective studies involving over 3,000 eviscerations, however, have failed to identify a single case of SO.

Once SO is developed, immunosuppressive therapy is the mainstay of treatment. When initiated promptly following injury, it is effective in controlling the inflammation and improving the prognosis. Mild cases may be treated with local application of corticosteroids and pupillary dilators. More severe or progressive cases require high-dose systemic corticosteroids for months to years. Patients who become resistant to corticosteroids or develop side effects of long-term corticosteroid therapy (osteoporosis and pathologic fractures, mental status changes, etc.), may be candidates for therapy with chlorambucil, cyclophosphamide, or ciclosporin.

Incorrect Options:

B. Blunt ocular trauma
Blunt trauma to the eye does not typically lead to sympathetic ophthalmia. SO is more commonly associated with penetrating trauma, where the eye's contents are exposed to the immune system.

C. Chemical injury
While chemical injuries can cause severe damage to the eye and lead to other complications like corneal scarring or loss of vision, they do not directly result in sympathetic ophthalmia.

D. Urinary tract infection
A urinary tract infection is unrelated to the development of sympathetic ophthalmia, which is specifically triggered by penetrating eye trauma, not systemic infections.

Key Takeaway: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a rare but serious condition most commonly caused by penetrating trauma to the eye. It is a delayed immune response that affects both eyes, and early intervention is crucial to manage inflammation and preserve vision.

questions.text: Which layer of cornea helps in maintaining hydration of stroma of cornea.
questions.solution:
• The corneal endothelium is responsible for maintaining the hydration of the cornea.
  • This is through a "Pump-Leak" mechanism where the active transport properties of the endothelium represent the "Pump" and the stromal swelling pressure represents the "Leak"

Incorrect Options:

A. Descemet's membrane
Descemet's membrane is the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium, but it does not directly regulate the hydration of the cornea. It acts as a protective barrier.

C. Epithelium
The epithelium is the outermost layer of the cornea and serves as a protective barrier against environmental damage. It does not play a major role in maintaining hydration of the stroma.

D. Stroma
The stroma is the middle layer of the cornea, composed mostly of collagen fibers and ground substance. While it is important for the structural integrity of the cornea, it does not actively regulate hydration.

Key Takeaway: The corneal endothelium is responsible for maintaining the hydration of the cornea through the "Pump-Leak" mechanism, ensuring proper hydration levels to maintain corneal clarity and function.

questions.text: Extra layer of cilia posterior to grey line
questions.solution:
Distichiasis is a rare disorder defined as the abnormal growth of lashes from the orifices of the meibomian glands on the posterior lamella of the tarsal plate.

Incorrect Options:

A. Tylosis
Tylosis refers to the thickening or hyperkeratosis of the skin, commonly on the palms and soles, and is not associated with the growth of eyelashes.

B. Madarosis
Madarosis refers to the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows, rather than the growth of an extra layer of lashes. It can occur due to various causes, including systemic diseases and trauma.

D.Trichiasis
Trichiasis is a condition where the eyelashes grow inwards, towards the eyeball, which can cause irritation or injury to the cornea. It involves misdirected eyelashes rather than an extra layer of lashes.

Key Takeaway: Distichiasis involves the abnormal growth of eyelashes from the meibomian gland orifices on the posterior lamella of the tarsal plate, and it can lead to irritation and discomfort due to the abnormal location of the lashes.

questions.text: U/L proptosis with B/L sixth nerve palsy:
questions.solution:
Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a condition where a blood clot forms in the cavernous sinus, a large vein located at the base of the skull. The condition often presents with unilateral proptosis that may later become bilateral. This occurs due to the venous congestion and obstruction in the cavernous sinus. Bilateral sixth nerve palsy is a hallmark sign of CST because the sixth cranial nerve (abducent nerve), which controls the lateral rectus muscles of the eye, passes through the cavernous sinus. The pressure from the thrombosis affects both sides, causing the bilateral palsy of the abducent nerve and resulting in double vision or an inability to move the eyes laterally.

Incorrect Options:

B. Thyroid ophthalmopathy
Thyroid eye disease, or thyroid ophthalmopathy, usually presents with bilateral proptosis but is not typically associated with bilateral sixth nerve palsy. It is caused by the swelling of extraocular muscles and orbital fat behind the eyes, leading to proptosis.

C. Retinoblastoma
Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina, typically seen in children. It does not commonly present with proptosis or bilateral sixth nerve palsy as primary symptoms. Retinoblastoma usually causes a leukocoria (white pupil reflex) rather than nerve palsies.

D. Orbital pseudotumor
Orbital pseudotumor is an inflammatory condition that affects the orbit, often leading to unilateral proptosis. While it can cause some cranial nerve palsies, including involvement of the sixth nerve, it does not typically result in the bilateral palsy seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Key Takeaway: Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a serious condition that can present with unilateral proptosis and bilateral sixth nerve palsy, due to the involvement of the sixth cranial nerve, which passes through the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: Drug used in patient with increased IOP& optic disc changes, ciliary congestion for Decrease IOP BY increases uveo scleral outflow:
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog used in the treatment of elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), particularly in conditions like glaucoma. It works by selectively stimulating the prostaglandin F2 alpha receptor, which increases the outflow of aqueous humor through the uveoscleral pathway. This increased outflow helps lower IOP, making latanoprost an effective treatment for conditions like primary open-angle glaucoma and ocular hypertension.

Incorrect Options:

B. Dorzolamide
Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases IOP by reducing the production of aqueous humor. It does not increase the outflow of aqueous humor but rather reduces its production, leading to a decrease in IOP.

C. Pilocarpine
Pilocarpine is a cholinergic agent that works by constricting the pupil, which opens the trabecular meshwork and increases aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular pathway. However, it is not primarily known for increasing uveoscleral outflow, which is the mechanism targeted by latanoprost.

D. Timolol
Timolol is a beta-blocker that decreases the production of aqueous humor, thus lowering IOP. It does not affect the outflow pathways directly, especially not the uveoscleral outflow, as latanoprost does.

Key Takeaway: Latanoprost works by increasing uveoscleral outflow, thereby lowering intraocular pressure. It is particularly useful in managing conditions like glaucoma where increased IOP is a concern.

In exudative retinal detachment, the subretinal fluid is not bound by a retinal break and can freely move within the subretinal space. A hallmark of ERD is the shifting fluid sign, where the subretinal fluid relocates to the most dependent part of the retina when the patient changes position. This feature helps distinguish ERD from other types of retinal detachment.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

(B) Tractional Retinal Detachment (TRD) - TRD occurs due to fibrovascular membranes pulling on the retina, commonly seen in conditions like proliferative diabetic retinopathy and retinopathy of prematurity. Since the detachment is caused by traction rather than fluid accumulation, shifting fluid is not observed.

(C) Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (RRD) - RRD is caused by a retinal tear or hole that allows vitreous fluid to seep underneath, leading to retinal separation. The fluid in RRD does not shift with body position since it is trapped under the retina due to the presence of a break.

(D) Retinal Dialysis - Retinal dialysis is a subtype of RRD where the retina is detached at the ora serrata. Like other forms of RRD, subretinal fluid does not shift with positional changes, as the fluid accumulates through a fixed retinal break.

Key Takeaways:

  • Shifting fluid sign is characteristic of exudative retinal detachment (ERD) due to freely moving subretinal fluid.
  • TRD and RRD do not exhibit shifting fluid because the detachment mechanisms involve traction or a retinal break, respectively.
  • Recognition of shifting fluid helps differentiate ERD from other types of retinal detachment.

questions.text: Esotropia is most commonly associated with:
questions.solution:
Esotropia is most commonly associated with hyperopia (farsightedness). In hyperopic individuals, the eyes need to accommodate (focus more) to see clearly, especially for near objects. This excessive accommodation can trigger an overactive convergence reflex, leading to accommodative esotropia, a common type of esotropia in children.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

(B) Myopia - Myopia (nearsightedness) causes blurred distance vision but does not require excessive accommodation. Since accommodative effort is not increased, myopia is not typically linked to esotropia. Instead, high myopia is more commonly associated with exotropia due to reduced fusional convergence.

(C) Presbyopia - Presbyopia is an age-related loss of near focusing ability due to reduced lens elasticity. It does not cause esotropia but rather leads to difficulty reading up close. Unlike hyperopia, presbyopia does not induce excessive accommodation in younger individuals.

(D) Astigmatism - Astigmatism results from an irregular corneal curvature, leading to blurred vision at all distances. It does not directly cause esotropia, although uncorrected astigmatism may contribute to visual strain.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hyperopia is the most common refractive error associated with esotropia due to excessive accommodative effort leading to increased convergence.
  • Accommodative esotropia is often seen in children with uncorrected hyperopia.
  • Myopia and astigmatism do not typically lead to esotropia and may instead be associated with other ocular misalignments, such as exotropia.

questions.text: Photostress test is used to differentiate:
questions.solution:
The photostress test helps differentiate macular disease from optic nerve disease in patients with unexplained central vision loss. In macular diseases (e.g., age-related macular degeneration), photoreceptor recovery after light exposure is prolonged. In contrast, optic nerve diseases do not significantly prolong recovery time, as the issue lies in signal conduction rather than photoreceptor function.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

(A) Cataract & Glaucoma - Cataracts cause lens opacification, while glaucoma affects the optic nerve. The photostress test is not useful for differentiating these conditions, as neither significantly alters photoreceptor recovery time.

(B) Cornea & Lens Diseases - Corneal and lens pathologies primarily cause refractive and opacity-related vision changes rather than affecting retinal photoreceptors, making the photostress test irrelevant for their diagnosis.

(D) Vitreous & Retina - Vitreous opacities (e.g., floaters, hemorrhage) do not affect retinal function in a way that would alter photostress recovery. However, retinal diseases, particularly those involving the macula, can cause prolonged recovery time.

Key Takeaways:

  • Photostress test helps distinguish macular disease (prolonged recovery) from optic nerve disease (normal recovery).
  • It is particularly useful for assessing unexplained central vision loss.
  • The test is not useful for diagnosing cataracts, glaucoma, or corneal and vitreous diseases.

questions.text: Lesion producing incongruous homonymous hemianopia with wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.solution:
Lesions of optic tract

The optic tract is a continuation of the optic nerve that relays information from the optic chiasm to the ipsilateral lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN), pretectal nuclei, and superior colliculus. The optic tract represents the first stage in the visual pathway in which visual information is transferred in a homonymous nature. Main characteristic feature of lesion involving whole optic tract is homonymous hemianopsia. A lesion in the left optic tract will cause right-sided homonymous hemianopsia, while a lesion in the right optic tract will cause left-sided homonymous hemianopsia.

Causes

The optic tract syndrome is characterized by a contralateral, incongruous homonymous hemianopia, contralateral relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), and optic atrophy due to retrograde axonal degeneration.Causes of optic tract lesions are also classified into intrinsic and extrinsic forms. Intrinsic lesions include demyelinating diseases and infarction. Such lesions produce optic tract syndrome type II. Extrinsic or compressive lesions are caused by pituitary craniopharyngioma, tumours of optic thalamus. Other causes include syphilitic meningitis, gumma and tubercular meningitis etc.

Signs and symptoms

Visual field-homonymous hemianopia

Incongruous homonymous hemianopia.

Wernicke's pupillary reaction- No pupillary reaction when light shown to the blind half of retina, but if light is shown to seeing half, pupil shows reaction.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

(B) Visual Cortex Lesion - Lesions in the visual cortex (occipital lobe) produce congruous homonymous hemianopiarather than incongruous defects. Since the pupillary light reflex is subcortical, visual cortex lesions do not cause Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil.

(C) Optic Radiations Lesion - Lesions in the optic radiations (parietal or temporal lobes) can cause homonymous hemianopia, but these defects are usually more congruous (i.e., similar in both eyes). Importantly, optic radiation lesions do not cause Wernicke’s pupil because the pupillary light reflex pathway is unaffected.

(D) Optic Nerve Lesion - Optic nerve damage causes monocular vision loss, not homonymous hemianopia. It can lead to an afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), but not Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil, which is specific to optic tract lesions.

Key Takeaways:

  • Optic tract lesions cause incongruous homonymous hemianopia and Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil.
  • Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil occurs when there is no pupillary reaction in the blind half but a normal reaction in the seeing half.
  • Visual cortex and optic radiation lesions do not produce Wernicke’s pupil.
  • Optic nerve lesions cause monocular blindness, not homonymous hemianopia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of Diabetes and hypertension presents to the OPD with complaints of diplopia and squint. On examination secondary deviation is seen to be more than primary deviation. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
B) Incomitant squint

Incomitant squint is a squint in which the angle of deviation differs depending upon the direction of gaze i.e, amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze. There are many type of incomitant squints (paralytic, restrictive, 'A' & 'V' pattern), however the most common type is Paralytic squint and the word incomitant squint is usually used for paralytic squint. Therefore, I will explain paralytic squint here Paralytic squint is the most common type of squint in adults. Paralytic squint is the strabismus resulting from complete or incomplete paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles. There are many causes like neurogenic (e.g. meningitis, cranial nerve palsy etc.), myogenic (myopathies), or neuromuscular junction lesions.

Symptoms of paralytic squint are :-

i) Diplopia : It is the main symptom. It is most marked in the direction of action of paralysed muscle. For example in left rectus palsy, the maximum diplopia occurs when patient tries to see horizontally on left side and in left superior oblique palsy (causes Dextrodepression) diplopia is maximum when patient tries to look downward and right.

It is worth noting here that in diplopia, if the images are separated horizontally it is probable that either a lateral or a medial recuts is affected; when the images are separated vertically or the image is tilted (torsion) it is likely that one or more of the vertical recti or the tilted (torsion) it is likely that one or more of the vertical recti or the obliques are affected.

ii) Other symptoms : Confusion, nausea & vertigo, ocular deviation,loss of stereopsis.

Signs of paralytic squint are :-

i) Secondary deviation is more than primary deviation:- Primary deviation is the deviation in the affected eye and is away from the action of paralysed muscle. Secondary deviation is the deviation of normal eye seen under cover, when the patient is made to fix with the squinting eye.

ii) Restriction of ocular movements

iii) Compensatory head posture :- Patients with a paralytic squint move their head such that the eyes occupy a position in the orbit where the angle of squint is minimal and this can avoid confusion and diplopia. Head is turned towards the action of paralysed muscle.

When the horizontal recti (medial or lateral) are affected, the characteristic posture is a turn of the face to right or left, e.g. in left lateral rectus palsy the head is turned to the left and in left medial recuts palsy the head is turned to the right. When a vertical rectus (superior or inferior) or an oblique muscle is affected, a tilt of the head to the right or left with depression or elevation of the chin is adopted to reduce both the vertical deviation and rotation, e.g in superior oblique palsy (dextrodepression of left eye is affected) the head is tilted to left so that the left eye can see down and medially.

iv) There is false projection or orientation

v) There is no amblyopia and visual acuity is normal as paralytic squint develops in adults when visual acuity has already develop

Incorrect Options Explanation:

(B) Incomitant Squint - While paralytic squint is a type of incomitant squint, the term incomitant squint is a broader category that includes both paralytic and restrictive squints. The defining feature of incomitant squint is that the angle of deviation varies depending on the direction of gaze, but since paralytic squint is the most common form of incomitant squint in adults, paralytic squint is the best answer.

(C) Restrictive Squint - Restrictive squint occurs due to mechanical restriction of ocular movements, such as in thyroid eye disease, trauma (orbital fractures), or fibrosis of extraocular muscles. Unlike paralytic squint, restrictive squint does not usually show secondary deviation greater than primary deviation.

(D) Pseudo Squint - Pseudo squint refers to a false appearance of strabismus without actual ocular misalignment, commonly seen in infants due to epicanthal folds or wide nasal bridges. It is not associated with diplopia or restricted ocular movements, making it an incorrect choice.

Key Takeaways:

  • Paralytic squint is the most common type of incomitant squint in adults.
  • Secondary deviation is greater than primary deviation, a key distinguishing feature of paralytic squint.
  • Diplopia is maximal in the direction of action of the affected muscle.
  • Diabetes and hypertension are common risk factors due to their association with cranial nerve palsies.
  • Restrictive squint is due to mechanical restriction, while pseudo squint is only a false appearance of strabismus.

questions.text: The movement is lost outward after trauma due to :
questions.solution:
The sixth cranial nerve (CN VI, Abducens nerve) innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abduction (outward movement) of the eye.

  • Key features of CN VI palsy:
    • Loss of lateral (outward) movement of the affected eye.
    • Diplopia (double vision) in horizontal gaze, especially when looking toward the affected side.
    • Head-turn compensation - The patient may turn their head towards the affected side to minimize diplopia.
    • Common causes include trauma, increased intracranial pressure (ICP), diabetes, hypertension, and brainstem lesions.

Since the question states loss of outward movement after trauma, the most likely nerve affected is CN VI (Abducens nerve), making option (C) the correct answer.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

(A) Third Nerve Palsy (Oculomotor Nerve Palsy)

  • CN III controls most extraocular muscles (superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, inferior oblique) and levator palpebrae superioris.
  • A lesion causes ptosis (drooping eyelid), a "down and out" eye position, and pupillary dilation.
  • Outward movement (abduction) is preserved because the lateral rectus (CN VI) is intact.
  • Incorrect answer because outward movement loss is specific to CN VI palsy.

(B) Trochlear Nerve Palsy (Fourth Nerve Palsy)

  • CN IV innervates superior oblique, which helps with intorsion and depression in adduction.
  • A lesion leads to vertical diplopia, worse when looking down (e.g., walking downstairs).
  • Patients compensate by tilting their head to the opposite side.
  • Incorrect answer because trochlear nerve palsy does not cause loss of outward movement.

(D) Facial Nerve Palsy (Seventh Nerve Palsy)

  • CN VII controls facial muscles, not extraocular movements.
  • Causes facial asymmetry, inability to close the eye (Bell’s phenomenon), and loss of forehead wrinkling.
  • Incorrect answer because CN VII does not control eye movements.

Key Takeaways:

  • Abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy causes loss of outward (lateral) eye movement.
  • Common causes include trauma, increased ICP, and vascular diseases.
  • Third nerve palsy causes ptosis and a "down and out" eye.
  • Trochlear nerve palsy causes vertical diplopia and head tilt.
  • Facial nerve palsy affects facial muscles, not eye movements.

questions.text: Middle aged women with b/l proptosis with restricted ocular movement and chemosis is euthyroid. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Nonspecific orbital inflammation (NSOI), also known as orbital inflammatory pseudotumor, idiopathic orbital inflammation ( IOI)and orbital inflammatory syndrome is the most common cause of painful orbital mass in adults. NSOI can be localized or diffuse. When localized, inflammation can affect the extraocular muscles (orbital myositis), lacrimal gland (dacryoadenitis), sclera (scleritis), uvea (uveitis), and the superior orbital fissure and cavernous sinus (Tolosa-Hunt syndrome). Others include periscleritis, perineuritis, and mass. When diffuse, NSOI may diffusely involve the orbital fatty tissues. NSOI is the third most common orbital disease after thyroid eye disease and orbital lymphoma. NSOI can both radiologically and clinically mimic a malignant process. Therefore, it is a diagnosis of exclusion, only after all other causes of inflammation have been eliminated. Treatment options are varied and can include surgery, steroids, chemotherapeutic agents and irradiation.

All patients with suspected NSOI require a full ophthalmic assessment/workup. NSOI is typically characterized by the abrupt onset of pain, proptosis and other inflammatory signs such as swelling and erythema. Unilateral presentation is more typical but bilateral presentations are not uncommon. Pediatric NSOI differs from the adult presentation and is more commonly characterized by bilateral manifestation, uveitis, disc edema and eosinophilia. Pain is the most common symptom in adult NSOI and occurs 58-69% of the time followed by diplopia (31-38%). Periorbital edema/swelling is the most common sign and occurs 75-79.2% of the time (figure) followed by proptosis (32-62.5%), EOM restriction (54.2%) red eye (48%), chemosis (29%), decreased vision (20.8%), and ptosis (16.7%).34-35 Therefore, physical examination of patients with suspected NSOI involves lid assessment (retraction/lid lag/lagophthalmos), orbital assessment (proptosis), extraocular muscles (restriction), globe (injection/chemosis), and optic nerve function (visual acuity/color plates/relative afferent pupillary defect). Because of the association between rheumatologic disease and NSOI the typical laboratory work-up for suspected NSOI should include a complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, thyroid function studies, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, antinuclear antibodies, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, angiotensin-converting enzyme level, rapid plasma reagin test, and rheumatoid factor.

Key features in the question:

  • Middle-aged woman
  • Bilateral proptosis
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Chemosis (conjunctival edema/swelling)

These symptoms are highly suggestive of Idiopathic Orbital Inflammation (IOI), also known as Orbital Inflammatory Pseudotumor, which is the correct answer.

Why Not the Other Options?

  • (A) Orbital Cellulitis: Usually unilateral, associated with fever, pain, and systemic infection signs.
  • (B) Thyroid Ophthalmopathy: Commonly presents with bilateral proptosis but typically has lid retraction and occurs in hyperthyroid patients. This patient is euthyroid.
  • (D) Orbital Lymphoma: Usually painless, slowly progressive proptosis without significant inflammation or restricted eye movements.

Key Features of Orbital Inflammatory Pseudotumor (IOI)

  • Sudden onset of painful proptosis
  • Bilateral (though unilateral can also occur)
  • Extraocular muscle restriction
  • Chemosis, conjunctival injection
  • Diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out infections, thyroid disease, and malignancy
  • Responds well to corticosteroids
